clinical_study.brief_title: Assessment of Combined Bowel Preparation for Capsule Endoscopy Study
clinical_study.official_title: Assessment of Combined Bowel Preparation for Capsule Endoscopy Study

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators are conducting a study to see if taking a bowel preparation before having a capsule endoscopy is more helpful than the standard preparation of not eating after 7 PM the night before a capsule endoscopy in making it easier to see the small bowel in order to find the source of gastrointestinal bleeding.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a single-blind, prospective randomized controlled study to determine if a combination of purgative agent, prokinetic agent, simethicone, and position will improve small bowel visualization, diagnostic yield, and completion rate of capsule endoscopy.

primary_outcome.measure: Improvement small bowel visualization, diagnostic yield, and complete rate of capsule endoscopy
primary_outcome.description: The primary endpoints of small bowel visualization quality, diagnostic yield, and completion rate will be compared between groups using Pearson's chi-square test.

secondary_outcome.description: secondary endpoints of safety outcomes and patient satisfaction with Pearson's chi-square test.
A group comparison for the secondary outcome of gastric transit time will be done using a two-sample t-test or Wilcoxon rank-sum test, as appropriate.

arm_group.description: One group will receive the standard bowel preparation, which consists of eating no solid foods after 7 p.m. the evening prior to the capsule endoscopy test and being able to consume clear liquids up to 4 hours prior to the capsule endoscopy test
